questions.question: What is the primary function of the motor system?
options: Generating movement from goals and intentions
questions.feedback: The motor system transforms goals and intentions into coordinated muscle activity.

questions.question: Which process is NOT required for producing movement?
questions.feedback: Sensory transduction belongs to sensory systems, not motor execution.

questions.question: Which structure is the main cortical output of the motor system?
questions.feedback: M1 is the main cortical output sending commands to the spinal cord.

questions.question: Where is the primary motor cortex located?
questions.feedback: Primary motor cortex lies in the frontal lobe, anterior to somatosensory cortex.

questions.question: Somatotopic organization in M1 means that:
options: Different body parts map to different cortical regions
All body parts are equally represented
questions.feedback: Different body parts are represented in distinct cortical regions.

questions.question: Which body parts occupy more cortical space in M1?
questions.feedback: Fine motor control requires larger cortical representation.

questions.question: What do neurons in primary motor cortex encode?
options: Patterns of movement via population activity
questions.feedback: Movement emerges from population activity encoding direction, force, and coordination.

questions.question: Motor control from cortex to spinal cord is largely:
questions.feedback: Motor cortex mainly controls the contralateral side of the body.

questions.question: Lower motor neurons are located in the:
options: Dorsal horn of the spinal cord
Ventral horn of the spinal cord
questions.feedback: Lower motor neurons reside in the ventral horn of the spinal cord.

questions.question: Why are lower motor neurons called the final common pathway?
options: All motor commands converge on them
questions.feedback: All descending motor commands converge on lower motor neurons.

questions.question: Which structure is the main site of motor execution?
questions.feedback: The spinal cord integrates commands and executes movement.

questions.question: Why is M1 alone insufficient for voluntary movement?
options: It cannot select or plan actions
It does not connect to the spinal cord
questions.feedback: Action selection and planning require additional motor areas.

questions.question: The supplementary motor area (SMA) is especially involved in:
questions.feedback: SMA supports internally generated and self-initiated movements.

questions.question: Which function is strongly associated with the SMA?
questions.feedback: SMA is critical for sequencing and bimanual coordination.

questions.question: The premotor cortex is mainly involved in:
questions.feedback: Premotor cortex links sensory cues to motor plans.

questions.question: What is the primary role of the basal nuclei?
questions.feedback: Basal nuclei regulate whether actions are initiated or suppressed.

questions.question: Basal nuclei do NOT:
questions.feedback: Basal nuclei do not project directly to muscles.

questions.question: The cerebellum is primarily involved in:
questions.feedback: The cerebellum refines movement execution through coordination and timing.

questions.question: What comparison does the cerebellum perform?
options: Sensory input vs motor cortex activity
questions.feedback: The cerebellum compares intended and actual movement.

questions.question: Damage to primary motor cortex typically causes:
questions.feedback: Primary motor cortex damage causes contralateral motor deficits.

questions.question: Why are reflexes usually preserved after M1 damage?
questions.feedback: Reflexes are mediated by spinal circuits.

questions.question: Damage to premotor cortex or SMA results in:
questions.feedback: These areas are critical for planning and sequencing actions.

questions.question: Apraxia is best described as:
options: Inability to plan movements despite normal strength
Loss of coordination due to weakness
questions.feedback: Apraxia reflects impaired motor planning, not execution.

questions.question: Basal nuclei damage primarily affects:
questions.feedback: Basal nuclei damage disrupts action selection.

questions.question: Parkinsonian disorders are characterized by:
questions.feedback: Parkinsonian disorders impair movement initiation.

questions.question: Which symptom is typical of Parkinsonâ€™s disease?
questions.feedback: Bradykinesia is a hallmark of Parkinsonian disorders.

questions.question: Cerebellar damage usually causes:
questions.feedback: Cerebellar damage affects accuracy and timing, not strength.

questions.question: Cerebellar ataxia includes which symptom?
questions.feedback: Dysmetria reflects inaccurate movement scaling.

questions.question: An intention tremor is associated with damage to the:
questions.feedback: Intention tremor is characteristic of cerebellar damage.

questions.question: Upper motor neuron lesions typically produce:
questions.feedback: Upper motor neuron lesions remove inhibitory control.

questions.question: Lower motor neuron lesions result in:
questions.feedback: Lower motor neuron damage disrupts the final motor pathway.

questions.question: Which feature distinguishes upper from lower motor neuron damage?
questions.feedback: Upper motor neuron damage increases tone; lower decreases it.

questions.question: Spinal cord lesions typically cause:
questions.feedback: Spinal cord lesions affect functions below the lesion level.

questions.question: Why does the level of a spinal cord lesion matter?
options: It determines which muscles are affected
questions.feedback: The lesion level defines which body regions lose control.

questions.question: Peripheral nerve damage typically results in:
questions.feedback: Peripheral nerve damage follows nerve distribution.

questions.question: Which deficit is common after peripheral nerve injury?
questions.feedback: Peripheral nerve damage disrupts reflex arcs.

questions.question: Motor planning primarily occurs:
questions.feedback: Planning precedes execution in voluntary movement.

questions.question: Which structure integrates descending motor commands with sensory input?
questions.feedback: The spinal cord integrates commands and sensory feedback.

questions.question: Which component of the motor system does NOT directly produce force?
questions.feedback: Basal nuclei modulate plans but do not generate force.

questions.question: Which structure mainly contributes to externally cued movement preparation?
questions.feedback: Premotor cortex links sensory cues to motor plans.

questions.question: Motor system organization is best described as:
questions.feedback: Motor control arises from distributed interacting circuits.

questions.question: Which statement best describes voluntary movement?
options: Generated by a single cortical area
Requires selection, planning, execution, and monitoring
Occurs only in the spinal cord
questions.feedback: Voluntary movement is a multi-stage distributed process.
